trans-unit.source: Manage a DocumentDB account | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Manage a DocumentDB account | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to manage your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to manage your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: Learn how to work with keys, consistency settings, and learn how to delete an account.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to work with keys, consistency settings, and learn how to delete an account.

trans-unit.source: When you create a DocumentDB account, the service generates two master access keys that can be used for authentication when the DocumentDB account is accessed.
trans-unit.target: When you create a DocumentDB account, the service generates two master access keys that can be used for authentication when the DocumentDB account is accessed.

trans-unit.source: By providing two access keys, DocumentDB enables you to regenerate the keys with no interruption to your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: By providing two access keys, DocumentDB enables you to regenerate the keys with no interruption to your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: In the Microsoft Azure Preview portal, access the Keys part from your DocumentDB Account blade to view, copy, and regenerate the access keys that are used to access your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: In the Microsoft Azure Preview portal, access the Keys part from your DocumentDB Account blade to view, copy, and regenerate the access keys that are used to access your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: 1. In the <linkText>Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title>, access your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: 1. In the <linkText>Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title>, access your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: 2.      In the Summary lens, click Keys.
trans-unit.target: 2.      In the Summary lens, click Keys.

trans-unit.source: 3.      On the Keys blade, click the Copy button to the right of the key you wish to copy.
trans-unit.target: 3.      On the Keys blade, click the Copy button to the right of the key you wish to copy.

trans-unit.source: You should change the access keys to your DocumentDB account periodically to help keep your connections more secure.
trans-unit.target: You should change the access keys to your DocumentDB account periodically to help keep your connections more secure.

trans-unit.source: Two access keys are assigned to enable you to maintain connections to the DocumentDB account using one access key while you regenerate the other access key.
trans-unit.target: Two access keys are assigned to enable you to maintain connections to the DocumentDB account using one access key while you regenerate the other access key.

trans-unit.source: Regenerating your access keys affects any applications that are dependent on the current key.
trans-unit.target: Regenerating your access keys affects any applications that are dependent on the current key.

trans-unit.source: All clients that use the access key to access the DocumentDB account must be updated to use the new key.
trans-unit.target: All clients that use the access key to access the DocumentDB account must be updated to use the new key.

trans-unit.source: If you have applications or cloud services using the DocumentDB account, you will lose the connections if you regenerate keys, unless you roll your keys.
trans-unit.target: If you have applications or cloud services using the DocumentDB account, you will lose the connections if you regenerate keys, unless you roll your keys.

trans-unit.source: The following steps outline the process involved in rolling your keys.
trans-unit.target: The following steps outline the process involved in rolling your keys.

trans-unit.source: 1. Update the access key in your application code to reference the secondary access key of the DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: 1. Update the access key in your application code to reference the secondary access key of the DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: 2. Regenerate the primary access key for your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: 2. Regenerate the primary access key for your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: In the <linkText>Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title>, access your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: In the <linkText>Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title>, access your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: 3.      In the Summary lens, click Keys.
trans-unit.target: 3.      In the Summary lens, click Keys.

trans-unit.source: 4.      On the Keys blade, click the Regenerate Primary command, then click Ok to confirm that you want to generate a new key.
trans-unit.target: 4.      On the Keys blade, click the Regenerate Primary command, then click Ok to confirm that you want to generate a new key.

trans-unit.source: 5. Once you have verified that the new key is available for use (approximately 5 minutes after regeneration), update the access key in your application code to reference the new primary access key.
trans-unit.target: 5. Once you have verified that the new key is available for use (approximately 5 minutes after regeneration), update the access key in your application code to reference the new primary access key.

trans-unit.source: 6. Regenerate the secondary access key.
trans-unit.target: 6. Regenerate the secondary access key.

trans-unit.source: Note that it can take several minutes before a newly generated key can be used to access your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: Note that it can take several minutes before a newly generated key can be used to access your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB supports four well-defined user-configurable data consistency levels to allow developers to make predictable consistency-availability-latency trade-offs.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB supports four well-defined user-configurable data consistency levels to allow developers to make predictable consistency-availability-latency trade-offs.

trans-unit.source: Strong consistency guarantees that read operations always return the value that was last written.
trans-unit.target: Strong consistency guarantees that read operations always return the value that was last written.

trans-unit.source: Bounded Staleness consistency guarantees that reads are not too out-of-date.
trans-unit.target: Bounded Staleness consistency guarantees that reads are not too out-of-date.

trans-unit.source: It specifically guarantees that the reads are no more than K versions older than the last written version.
trans-unit.target: It specifically guarantees that the reads are no more than K versions older than the last written version.

trans-unit.source: Session consistency guarantees monotonic reads (you never read old data, then new, then old again), monotonic writes (writes are ordered), and that you read the most recent writes within any single client’s viewpoint.
trans-unit.target: Session consistency guarantees monotonic reads (you never read old data, then new, then old again), monotonic writes (writes are ordered), and that you read the most recent writes within any single client’s viewpoint.

trans-unit.source: Eventual consistency guarantees that read operations always read a valid subset of writes and will eventually converge.
trans-unit.target: Eventual consistency guarantees that read operations always read a valid subset of writes and will eventually converge.

trans-unit.source: *Note that by default, DocumentDB accounts are provisioned with Session level consistency.
trans-unit.target: *Note that by default, DocumentDB accounts are provisioned with Session level consistency.

trans-unit.source: For additional information on DocumentDB consistency settings, see the <linkText>Consistency Level</linkText><title></title> section.*
trans-unit.target: For additional information on DocumentDB consistency settings, see the <linkText>Consistency Level</linkText><title></title> section.*

trans-unit.source: 1. In the <linkText>Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title>, access your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: 1. In the <linkText>Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title>, access your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: 2.      In the Configuration lens, click Default Consistency.
trans-unit.target: 2.      In the Configuration lens, click Default Consistency.

trans-unit.source: 3.      On the Default Consistency blade, select the default consistency level you want for your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: 3.      On the Default Consistency blade, select the default consistency level you want for your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: 4.      Click Save.
trans-unit.target: 4.      Click Save.

trans-unit.source: 5. The progress of the operation may be monitored via the Azure Preview portal Notifications hub.
trans-unit.target: 5. The progress of the operation may be monitored via the Azure Preview portal Notifications hub.

trans-unit.source: Note that it can take several minutes before a change to the default consistency setting takes affect across your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: Note that it can take several minutes before a change to the default consistency setting takes affect across your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: To remove a DocumentDB account that you are no longer using, use the Delete command on the DocumentDB Account blade.
trans-unit.target: To remove a DocumentDB account that you are no longer using, use the Delete command on the DocumentDB Account blade.

trans-unit.source: 1. In the <linkText>Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title>, access the DocumentDB Account you wish to delete.
trans-unit.target: 1. In the <linkText>Azure Preview portal</linkText><title></title>, access the DocumentDB Account you wish to delete.

trans-unit.source: 2.      On the DocumentDB Account blade, click the Delete command.
trans-unit.target: 2.      On the DocumentDB Account blade, click the Delete command.

trans-unit.source: 3. On the resulting confirmation blade, type the DocumentDB Account name to confirm that you want to delete the account.
trans-unit.target: 3. On the resulting confirmation blade, type the DocumentDB Account name to confirm that you want to delete the account.

trans-unit.source: 4.      Click the Delete button on the confirmation blade.
trans-unit.target: 4.      Click the Delete button on the confirmation blade.

trans-unit.source: Learn how to <linkText>get started with your DocumentDB account</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to <linkText>get started with your DocumentDB account</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about DocumentDB, see the Azure DocumentDB documentation on <linkText>azure.com</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about DocumentDB, see the Azure DocumentDB documentation on <linkText>azure.com</linkText><title></title>.
